State Space Algorithm

Originally written: June 19, 2020

Recently, I imÂ­pleÂ­mented the state space alÂ­goÂ­rithm in Racket. It's a simÂ­ple alÂ­goÂ­rithm that can ï¬nd a goal state in n-diÂ­menÂ­sional Euclidean space. All one needs is a comÂ­putable funcÂ­tion, a startÂ­ing doÂ­main, and a goal value.

How does it work?

For exÂ­amÂ­ple, let's say we want to ï¬nd an inÂ­put for coÂ­sine that gives us one of the zeÂ­ros for the doÂ­main 0 to 2Ï€. Of course, there's no need to use the alÂ­goÂ­rithm in this case. We could look at a unit cirÂ­cle and ï¬nd that apÂ­plyÂ­ing coÂ­sine with the value 3Ï€/2 gives us zero. Alternatively, the value of Ï€/2 works just as well. Shortly, we'll disÂ­cover how the alÂ­goÂ­rithm will nonÂ­deÂ­terÂ­minÂ­isÂ­tiÂ­cally reÂ­turn one of these two zeÂ­rosâ€“and in this case, we don't faÂ­vor eiÂ­ther state. Any zero will do.

The main idea of the alÂ­goÂ­rithm is to tighten the doÂ­main around a state that satÂ­isÂ­ï¬es the goal. This process is done itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tively. Every crank, the code will genÂ­erÂ­ate K ranÂ­dom guesses for a goal-satÂ­isÂ­fyÂ­ing state within the curÂ­rent doÂ­main. The K paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter has to be any posÂ­iÂ­tive inÂ­teÂ­ger, but you get to choose it. I recÂ­omÂ­mend tryÂ­ing difÂ­ferÂ­ent valÂ­ues for K to see how that afÂ­fects the outÂ­come.

The best state out of the set of Kâ€“i.e. the guess that gives an outÂ­put closÂ­est to the goalâ€“will be set aside. This guess is seÂ­lected by ï¬ndÂ­ing the K range value that minÂ­iÂ­mizes the forÂ­mula beÂ­low. Note that y is the guess and yg is the goal value.

$$|y - y_g|$$

Obviously, in the beÂ­ginÂ­ning, the best state is likely far off from the goal state. The chance to genÂ­erÂ­ate a satÂ­isÂ­ï¬Â­able guess inÂ­creases as the doÂ­main shrinks around a goal-satÂ­isÂ­fyÂ­ing state, which hapÂ­pens every itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion.

To get this new doÂ­main, there are a few steps to folÂ­low. First, let's ï¬nd the avÂ­erÂ­age of the abÂ­solute valÂ­ues of the difÂ­ferÂ­ences of the K range valÂ­ues and the goal value, which we'll call u.

$$u = \sum_{i=0}^{K} | y_i - y_g |$$

Next, we'll need a so-called epÂ­silon value to scale our new doÂ­main. To comÂ­pute it, use the folÂ­lowÂ­ing forÂ­mula:

$$\epsilon = \frac{|y - y_g|}{u}$$

The nuÂ­merÂ­aÂ­tor is the abÂ­solute value of the difÂ­ferÂ­ence of the best K range value and the goalâ€“which we comÂ­puted earÂ­lier. The deÂ­nomÂ­iÂ­naÂ­tor is the u we just comÂ­puted. So, you should only be plugÂ­ging in numÂ­bers here.

Finally, inÂ­sert our preÂ­reqÂ­uiÂ­site work into this forÂ­mula to genÂ­erÂ­ate the new doÂ­main. Note that the x is the best state out of the set of K states. The b is the end value of the curÂ­rent doÂ­main; the a is the beÂ­ginnning of the doÂ­main.

$$x \pm \epsilon \frac{b - a}{2}$$

The alÂ­goÂ­rithm will thus genÂ­erÂ­ate K range valÂ­ues and use the best one to creÂ­ate the new doÂ­main for the next itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion. We'll conÂ­tinue this process unÂ­til one of the genÂ­erÂ­ated guesses is within an erÂ­ror bound that we choose.

Conclusion

Astute readÂ­ers may have noÂ­ticed that this is a variÂ­aÂ­tion of a beam search. According to Wikipedia, beam search is a heurisÂ­tic search alÂ­goÂ­rithm that exÂ­plores a graph by exÂ­pandÂ­ing the most promisÂ­ing node in a limÂ­ited set. In this case, our â€œgraphâ€ is the doÂ­main. Thus, we are workÂ­ing over a conÂ­tinÂ­uÂ­ous space rather than a disÂ­crete space; howÂ­ever, since we can efÂ­fecÂ­tively reÂ­duce the search space, the alÂ­goÂ­rithm works. Well, works is fudgey term. I beÂ­lieve that the alÂ­goÂ­rithm can someÂ­times fail to ï¬nd a soÂ­luÂ­tion since it isn't mathÂ­eÂ­matÂ­iÂ­cally guarÂ­enteed to conÂ­verge the doÂ­main around a goal-sasÂ­tiÂ­fyÂ­ing state. Increasing the K paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter should helpâ€“more guesses inÂ­creases the chance of one them beÂ­ing good.

Here is the code for my comÂ­plete soÂ­luÂ­tion. As a reÂ­minder, the alÂ­goÂ­rithm is lookÂ­ing for a zero of the coÂ­sine funcÂ­tion for the doÂ­main 0 to 2Ï€. To note, K is set to 3, and the erÂ­ror bound is set to .01.

For a sinÂ­gle run, I got a state value of about 1.566, which is close to Ï€/2. Since Ï€/2 is one of the valid zeÂ­ros, the alÂ­goÂ­rithm's outÂ­come is what we exÂ­pected. You should keep in mind that it's posÂ­siÂ­ble to get a state value near 3Ï€/2, the other zero. Consider runÂ­ning the alÂ­goÂ­rithm mulÂ­tiÂ­ple times to get a feel for how things work.
